**Kit Kat** is a chocolate-covered [wafer](/wiki/Wafer "Wafer") bar
[confection](/wiki/Confectionery "Confectionery") created by
[Rowntree's](/wiki/Rowntree%27s "Rowntree's") of [York](/wiki/York "York"),
United Kingdom, and is now produced globally by [Nestlé](/wiki/Nestl%C3%A9
"Nestlé"), which acquired Rowntree in 1988,[1] with the exception of the
United States where it is made under license by H.B. Reese Candy Company, a
division of [The Hershey Company](/wiki/The_Hershey_Company "The Hershey
Company"). The standard bars consist of two or four fingers composed of three
layers of wafer, separated and covered by an outer layer of chocolate. Each
finger can be snapped from the bar separately. There are many different
flavours of Kit Kat, including milk, white, and dark chocolate.

## History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: History")]

Use of the name Kit Kat or Kit Cat for a type of food goes back to the 18th
century, when mutton pies known as a Kit-Kat were served at meetings of the
political [Kit-Cat Club](/wiki/Kit-Cat_Club "Kit-Cat Club") in London owned by
pastry chef Christopher Catling.[2][3]

The origins of what is now known as the Kit Kat brand go back to 1911, when
[Rowntree's](/wiki/Rowntree%27s "Rowntree's"), a confectionery company based
in [York](/wiki/York "York") in the United Kingdom, trademarked the terms Kit
Cat and Kit Kat. The names were not used immediately and Kit Kat first
appeared in the 1920s, when Rowntree's launched a brand of boxed chocolates
entitled Kit Cat. This continued into the 1930s, when Rowntree's shifted focus
and production onto its [Black Magic](/wiki/Black_Magic_\(chocolates\) "Black
Magic \(chocolates\)") and Dairy Box brands. With the promotion of alternative
products the Kit Cat brand decreased and was eventually discontinued.[4] The
original four-finger bar was developed after a worker at Rowntree's York
Factory put a suggestion in a recommendation box for a snack that "a man could
take to work in his pack".[5] The bar launched on 29 August 1935, under the
title of Rowntree's Chocolate Crisp (priced at [2d](/wiki/Old_penny_sterling
"Old penny sterling")), and was sold in London and throughout Southern
England.[6]

The product's official title of Rowntree's Chocolate Crisp was renamed Kit Kat
Chocolate Crisp in 1937, the same year that Kit Kat began to incorporate
"Break" into its recognisable advertising strategy.[4] The colour scheme and
first flavour variation to the brand came in 1942, owing to [World War
II](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), when food shortages prompted an
alteration in the recipe. The flavour of Kit Kat was changed to dark
chocolate; the packaging abandoned its Chocolate Crisp title, and was adorned
in blue.[7] After the war the title was altered to Kit Kat and resumed its
original milk recipe and red packaging.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/KitKat.jpg/220px-
KitKat.jpg)](/wiki/File:KitKat.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:KitKat.jpg "Enlarge")

4-finger US Kit Kat

Following on from its success in the United Kingdom, in the 1940s Kit Kat was
exported to Canada, South Africa, Ireland, Australia, and New Zealand. In
1958, Donald Gilles, the executive at JWT Orland, created the iconic
advertising line "Have a Break, Have a Kit Kat". The brand further expanded in
the 1970s when Rowntree created a new distribution factory in Germany to meet
European demand, and established agreements to distribute the brand in the USA
and Japan through the Hershey and [Fujiya](/wiki/Fujiya_Co. "Fujiya Co.")
companies, respectively.[4]

In June 1988, Swiss company Nestlé acquired Kit Kat through the purchase of
Rowntree's. This gave Nestlé global control over the brand, except in the
US,[8] and production and distribution increased with new facilities in Japan
and additional manufacturing operations set up in Malaysia, India and
China.[4]

The Hershey Company has a licence to produce Kit Kat bars in the United States
which dates from 1970, when Hershey executed a licensing agreement with
Rowntree. Nestlé, which has a substantial presence in the US, had to honour
the licensing agreement when it bought Rowntree in 1988 which allowed Hershey
to retain the Kit Kat licence so long as Hershey was not sold. As Kit Kat is
one of Hershey's top five brands in the US market, the Kit Kat licence was a
key factor in Hershey's failed attempt to attract a serious buyer in
2002.[9][10]

Variants in the traditional chocolate bar first appeared in 1996 when Kit Kat
Orange, the first flavour variant, was introduced in the United Kingdom. Its
success was followed by several varieties including mint and caramel, and in
1999 Kit Kat Chunky was launched and received favourably by international
consumers. Variations on the traditional Kit Kat have continued to develop
throughout the 2000s. In 2000, Nestlé acquired Fujiya's share of the brand in
Japan, and also expanded its marketplace in Japan, Russia, Turkey, and
Venezuela, in addition to markets in Eastern and Central Europe.[4] Throughout
the decade Kit Kat has introduced dozens of flavours and line extensions
within specific consumer markets, and celebrated its 75th anniversary on 10
October 2009.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The traditional bar has four fingers which each measure approximately 1
centimetre (0.4 in) by 9 centimetres (3.5 in). A two-finger bar was launched
in the 1930s, and has remained the company's best-selling biscuit brand ever
since.[6] The 1999 Kit Kat Chunky (known as Big Kat and Kit Kat Extra Crispy
in the US) has one large finger approximately 2.5 centimetres (1 in) wide. Kit
Kat bars contain varying numbers of fingers depending on the market, ranging
from the half-finger sized Kit Kat Petit in Japan, to the three-fingered
variants in Arabia, to the twelve-finger family-size bars in Australia and
France. Kit Kat bars are sold individually and in bags, boxes and multi-packs.
In Ireland, France, the UK and America Nestlé also produces a Kit Kat [ice
cream](/wiki/Ice_cream "Ice cream"), and in Australia and Malaysia, Kit Kat
[Drumsticks](/wiki/Drumstick_\(ice_cream\) "Drumstick \(ice
cream\)").[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In 2010, a new £5 million manufacturing line was opened by Nestlé in York.
This will produce more than a billion Kit Kat bars each year.[11]

## Global confection[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Global confection")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/KitKat_World_Map.png/220px-
KitKat_World_Map.png)](/wiki/File:KitKat_World_Map.png)

[](/wiki/File:KitKat_World_Map.png "Enlarge")

Countries where Kit Kat is marketed.

Kit Kat bars are produced in 16 countries by Nestlé: [Brazil](/wiki/Brazil
"Brazil"), [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"), UK, [Canada](/wiki/Canada
"Canada"), [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia"), [New
Zealand](/wiki/New_Zealand "New Zealand"), [South Africa](/wiki/South_Africa
"South Africa"), [Germany](/wiki/Germany "Germany"), [Russia](/wiki/Russia
"Russia"), [Japan](/wiki/Kit_Kats_in_Japan "Kit Kats in Japan"),
[China](/wiki/China "China"), [Malaysia](/wiki/Malaysia "Malaysia"),
[Thailand](/wiki/Thailand "Thailand"), [India](/wiki/India "India"),
[Turkey](/wiki/Turkey "Turkey"), [United Arab
Emirates](/wiki/United_Arab_Emirates "United Arab Emirates"),
[Bulgaria](/wiki/Bulgaria "Bulgaria") and [Algeria](/wiki/Algeria "Algeria").
Kit Kat bars in the United States are produced under licence by The Hershey
Company, a Nestlé competitor, due to a prior licensing agreement with
Rowntree. The year 2003 was a turning point for the Kit Kat bar as well as the
confectionery industry in general. The popularity of [low carb](/wiki/Low_carb
"Low carb") diets and the push to healthier eating stifled sales growth in
many parts of the world. In addition, fierce competition from
[Cadbury](/wiki/Cadbury "Cadbury")'s newly formed [Dairy
Milk](/wiki/Cadbury_Dairy_Milk "Cadbury Dairy Milk") superbrand also
contributed to sales of the Kit Kat decreasing considerably in its home market
of the UK, and threatened to depose it from its No.1 position.[12][13] The
solution adopted by Nestlé and others was to increase dramatically the number
of new and unique variations of their confections and market them as [limited
or special editions](/wiki/Special_edition "Special edition"), whereby they
would usually only be available for a few months at a time so as not to impact
the sales of their permanent edition counterparts.[14] The strategy initially
reversed the decline of the Kit Kat[15] and has been adopted worldwide by
Nestlé, Hershey, [Mars](/wiki/Mars_Incorporated "Mars Incorporated") and
others with similar success.[16][17]

This has resulted in many new flavours and varieties of the Kit Kat and other
confections appearing globally since then. While some flavours have been hits,
many have flopped, alienating some consumers in the process, causing Nestlé to
scale back on new releases.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

In September 2006, Nestlé announced that they would be cutting 645 jobs in
their York factory and moving [Smarties](/wiki/Smarties "Smarties") production
to their [Hamburg](/wiki/Hamburg "Hamburg") factory in which two thirds of
production was already taking place. They stated that this move would allow
for a £20 million investment to modernise the antiquated York factory and
improve Kit Kat production.[18]

As [dark chocolate](/wiki/Chocolate#Classification "Chocolate") has seen
increased demand and favour worldwide because of its purported health
benefits, September 2006 saw the launch of the four-finger Kit Kat Fine Dark
in the UK as a permanent edition, as well as new packaging for the entire
brand.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation
needed")_] Hershey had sold the four-finger Kit Kat Dark in the US several
years previously as a limited edition, and has begun doing so again.[19]

Nestlé now manufactures two finger Kit Kats with natural flavourings, and for
the first time, Kit Kats in this format are suitable for vegans.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] It is
not known at this date whether or not other varieties will follow suit. In
2014, Kit Kat was ranked the third best selling chocolate bar in the UK, after
[Dairy Milk](/wiki/Cadbury_Dairy_Milk "Cadbury Dairy Milk") and
[Galaxy](/wiki/Galaxy_\(chocolate\) "Galaxy \(chocolate\)").[20]

## Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Design")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/5/5d/Kit-Kat-Wrapper-
Small.jpg/220px-Kit-Kat-Wrapper-Small.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kit-Kat-Wrapper-
Small.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kit-Kat-Wrapper-Small.jpg "Enlarge")

The US packaging

When first introduced, the original Rowntree's Chocolate Crisp bar had a red
wrapper, which briefly became blue between 1945–1947. As a result of milk
shortages after the end of World War II, the milk chocolate coating was
suspended and a dark chocolate was used instead during that period.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

Since its introduction in the 1970s, the Hershey's Kit Kat packaging and
advertising in the United States differed from the branding used in every
other country where it was sold. In 2002, Hershey Kit Kats adopted the slanted
[ellipse](/wiki/Ellipse "Ellipse") logo used worldwide by Nestlé, though the
ellipse was red and the text white. The US version of "Kit Kat Chunky" is
known as "Big Kat".

In the United Kingdom, the product has traditionally been wrapped in silver
foil and an outer paper band. In 2001, [flow
wrap](/w/index.php?title=Flow_wrap&action=edit&redlink=1 "Flow wrap \(page
does not exist\)") plastic was substituted as the confectionery's
packaging.[21]

In Norway, a similar product is manufactured by [Mondelēz
International](/wiki/Mondel%C4%93z_International "Mondelēz International") and
sold as [Kvikk Lunsj](/wiki/Kvikk_Lunsj "Kvikk Lunsj"); Kvikk Lunsj XXL is
similar to a Kit Kat Chunky.

## Marketing and
promotion[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Marketing and promotion")]

After launching in the 1930s, Rowntree's Chocolate Crisp was originally
advertised as "the biggest little meal" and "the best companion to a cup of
tea". During World War II, Kit Kat was depicted as a valuable wartime
foodstuff, with the slogan "what active people need". 'Kitty the Kat' arrived
in the late 1940s to emphasise the "rich full cream milk" qualities of the bar
and, thanks to contemporary improvements in production methods, also
highlighted the new and improved 'snap' by responding to a biscuit being
broken off screen. The first Kit Kat poster appeared in 1951, and the first
colour TV advertisement appeared in 1969.

Since 1958, the slogan for the Kit Kat in the UK and elsewhere has been "Have
a break... have a Kit Kat". However, in 1995, Nestlé sought to trademark the
"Have a break" portion. After a ten-year legal battle, which was contested by
rival Mars, the [European Court of Justice](/wiki/European_Court_of_Justice
"European Court of Justice") ruled on 7 July 2005 to send the case back to the
[British courts](/wiki/Courts_of_the_United_Kingdom "Courts of the United
Kingdom").[22] In 2004, Nestlé UK used the slogan "Make the most of your
break",[23] but later returned to the original slogan.

The United States also used the short-lived slogan, "Tastes So Good, You'll
Roar", in the early 1980s. The TV commercial most known from this slogan
involves a young man biting into one of the Kit Kat bars in a grocery store,
and roaring like a lion so loudly the whole store shakes violently, knocking
items from the shelves. Another short-lived US slogan was "That's What You
Want", whose television adverts showed people pulling unlikely foodstuffs from
their pockets or purses, before rejecting them in favour of a Kit Kat.

The "classic" American version of the "Gimme a Break" Kit Kat jingle (in use
in the US since 1986) was written by Ken Shuldman (copy) and Michael A. Levine
(music) for the [DDB Advertising Agency](/wiki/DDB_Worldwide "DDB Worldwide").
Versions of the original have been covered by [Carrie
Underwood](/wiki/Carrie_Underwood "Carrie Underwood"), [Shawn
Colvin](/wiki/Shawn_Colvin "Shawn Colvin"), and many studio singers, as well
as people who have appeared on-camera in the commercials. The jingle was cited
in a study by [University of Cincinnati](/wiki/University_of_Cincinnati
"University of Cincinnati") researcher James J. Kellaris as one of the top ten
"[earworms](/wiki/Earworm "Earworm")" – bits of melody that become stuck in
your head. Another version of the advertising jingle 'Gimme a break' created
for Kit Kat "Factory" commercial in the US was an original recording by
[Andrew W.K.](/wiki/Andrew_W.K. "Andrew W.K.") W.K. was hired to write a new
musical version for their "Gimme a break" slogan. Variations on the Andrew
W.K. advertisement included executive dance routines in corporate offices and
a network newsroom. However, the "classic" song has also been used again since
the newer version first aired in 2004.

A 1989 United Kingdom advertisement for Kit Kat, in which a zoo photographer
"takes a break" from waiting for pandas to appear in an enclosure and misses
them performing a dance routine, came in 30th in [Channel 4](/wiki/Channel_4
"Channel 4")'s "100 Greatest Adverts" poll in 2000.

The Maltese tour boat [MV _Lady Davinia_](/wiki/HMS_Greetham_\(M2632\) "HMS
Greetham \(M2632\)") had a distinctive red and white Kit Kat paint scheme
before she sank in 2008.

In late 2004 through to the end of 2006, Nestlé Rowntree sponsored the English
football club [York City F.C.](/wiki/York_City_F.C. "York City F.C."). As a
result, the club's home-ground, [Bootham Crescent](/wiki/Bootham_Crescent
"Bootham Crescent"), was renamed to KitKat Crescent.[24]

In an 2012 advertising campaign in the UK and Ireland, several new flavours of
Chunky Kit Kat were marketed, with consumers being asked to vote for their
favourite. Selecting from white chocolate, double chocolate, peanut butter,
and orange, Peanut butter was the winner by having 47% of votes. A similar
campaign occurred in 2013 with mint, coconut, hazelnut and chocolate fudge.

### Association with
Android[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section:
Association with Android")]

In September 2013, it was announced that [version 4.4](/wiki/Android_KitKat
"Android KitKat") of [Google](/wiki/Google "Google")'s
[Android](/wiki/Android_\(operating_system\) "Android \(operating system\)")
mobile operating system would be named "KitKat".[25] Google
[licensed](/wiki/Brand_licensing "Brand licensing") the name from Nestlé, with
no money changing hands.[26] A promotion ran in numerous countries with
specially branded Android Kit Kat bars to win [Nexus
7](/wiki/Nexus_7_\(2013_version\) "Nexus 7 \(2013 version\)") devices and
[Google Play Store](/wiki/Google_Play_Store "Google Play Store") credit.[27]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/73/A_Kitkat_bar_statue_in_Googleplex_Headquarters.jpg/220px-
A_Kitkat_bar_statue_in_Googleplex_Headquarters.jpg)](/wiki/File:A_Kitkat_bar_statue_in_Googleplex_Headquarters.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:A_Kitkat_bar_statue_in_Googleplex_Headquarters.jpg "Enlarge")

A Kitkat bar statue in Googleplex Headquarters

### Fairtrade[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Fairtrade")]

In December 2009, it was announced that the four finger variety of Kit Kat
would use [Fairtrade](/wiki/Fairtrade_certification "Fairtrade certification")
chocolate (at least in Britain and Ireland) from January 2010.[28] It has also
been announced that the Fairtrade Kit Kat promotion will be extended to the
finger edition as of January 2010.[29]

### Golden ticket draw[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Golden ticket draw")]

During the first three weeks of _[Big Brother Series
7](/wiki/Big_Brother_2006_\(UK\) "Big Brother 2006 \(UK\)")_ , Channel 4
conducted a promotion in conjunction with Nestlé to distribute 100 "golden
tickets" randomly throughout Kit Kats, in a style reminiscent of the story
_[Charlie and the Chocolate Factory](/wiki/Charlie_and_the_Chocolate_Factory
"Charlie and the Chocolate Factory")_. Members of the public finding these
tickets were permitted to use them to give themselves a chance to become a
_Big Brother_ housemate and bypass the standard auditions process.

Golden ticket holders were invited to a television show where one of them,
[Susie Verrico](/wiki/Susie_Verrico "Susie Verrico"), was chosen to enter the
House by [Aisleyne Horgan-Wallace](/wiki/Aisleyne_Horgan-Wallace "Aisleyne
Horgan-Wallace"), picking a ball out of a machine at random.

This contest caused some controversy, with the [Advertising Standards
Authority](/wiki/Advertising_Standards_Authority_\(United_Kingdom\)
"Advertising Standards Authority \(United Kingdom\)") saying that the terms
and conditions of the draw should have been made clearer in related
advertisements, and that an independent adjudicator should have been present
before and during the draw.[30]

## Varieties[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: Varieties")]

### Flavours[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Flavours")]

Many varieties of Kit Kat have existed, either permanently or as limited
editions, such as those sold to commemorate festivals such as [St. Valentine's
Day](/wiki/St._Valentine%27s_Day "St. Valentine's Day").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] In
Japan, Nestlé has introduced over 200 different flavours since 2000,[31]
including [ginger ale](/wiki/Ginger_ale "Ginger ale"), [soy
sauce](/wiki/Soy_sauce "Soy sauce"), [creme brulee](/wiki/Creme_brulee "Creme
brulee"), [green tea](/wiki/Green_tea "Green tea"), [sake](/wiki/Sake "Sake"),
and banana.[32] The flavours are designed to appeal to younger buyers,[33] and
are often bought as good-luck gifts as the brand name echoes the Japanese
phrase "Kitto Katsu", roughly translating as "surely win."[31]

The Kit Kat Orange was the first flavour variant to be introduced in the
United Kingdom, in 1996 and 1998 in Ireland. It was followed in 1997 by the
Kit Kat Dark and Kit Kat Mint.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] All
three were available as permanent editions of the two-finger multipack in the
United Kingdom, along with the Kit Kat Original, the Kit Kat White, and from
2012 the Kit Kat Cookies & Cream.

A wide variety of promotional items exist, ranging from traditional
merchandise (such as mugs, pens, oven gloves and tea-towels) to less common
items such as coats for small dogs. Recently in
Japan,[_[when?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers")_] Kit Kats have come packaged
with CD singles, and a special limited edition double pack of Kit Kat Crispy
Monogatari came bundled with a mini book featuring six short stories, one of
which was written by [Koji Suzuki](/wiki/Koji_Suzuki "Koji Suzuki"), author of
the [Ring cycle](/wiki/Ring_\(Suzuki_novel\) "Ring \(Suzuki novel\)") series.
In Japan, Kit Kats are also available in jars that are dispensed from vending
machines.

### Forms[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Forms")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bb/Kit-Kat-Type-
Variations.jpg/280px-Kit-Kat-Type-Variations.jpg)](/wiki/File:Kit-Kat-Type-
Variations.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Kit-Kat-Type-Variations.jpg "Enlarge")

Kit Kat varieties: Pop Choc, regular and Chunky (or Big Kat)

The 'standard' Kit Kat finger bars can come in a variety of presentations and
nutritional values. The bars can come in a miniature form of two finger mini
bars, or a larger standard four, or in some cases, three, fingered bars.

The standard size has been upgraded in several cases up to a 'monster Size'
bar, which can include up to five or eight fingers. Large single-fingered
"Chunky Kit Kats" were launched in the United Kingdom in 1998 and have been
sold in a variety of flavours.

Other forms and shapes include "Choc'n'Go" individually wrapped fingers from
France, a twelve-finger "Family Block which is available in New Zealand, " in
Australia, round bite-sized "Pop Choc" pieces, square "Kubes",
[praline](/wiki/Praline "Praline")-filled "Senses", a yoghurt with Kit Kat
pieces, and a Kit Kat [ice cream cone](/wiki/Ice_cream_cone "Ice cream cone").

In the 1980s, a Kit Kat with five shorter fingers was sold in vending machines
in the UK.[34]

The Japanese _Bake 'N Tasty Mini Kit Kats Custard Pudding Flavour_ was
launched in 2014. The bar must be baked in an oven before consumption, and the
surface sugar caramelises in the process.[35]

In 2015, a new luxury and giftable variant of Kit Kat called Kit Kat Rubies
was launched in Malaysia. Comes with the box of 20 small bars, the Kit Kat
Rubies bar made with the premium chocolate truffle cream and imported roasted
hazelnut pieces.[36]

As of 2017, U.S. variants include the standard and king-size four-finger bars,
standard bars covered with white or dark chocolate, snack-size orange-covered
bars for Halloween, bagged wrapped one-finger miniatures (original and
assorted), unwrapped minis, a redesigned Big Kat, and a king-size Big Kat (two
of the new Big Kat bars).[37]

## Chocolatory
Melbourne[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Chocolatory Melbourne")]

Kit Kat has opened a Chocolatory in the [Melbourne Central Shopping
Centre](/wiki/Melbourne_Central_Shopping_Centre "Melbourne Central Shopping
Centre") in [Melbourne, Australia](/wiki/Melbourne,_Australia "Melbourne,
Australia"). The dedicated shop allows customers to use touch screens to craft
their own Kit Kat from a selection of chocolates and ingredients which are
then created for them on site while they wait. [38]

## Criticism and
controversy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=12 "Edit
section: Criticism and controversy")]

In March 2010, Kit Kat was targeted for a boycott by
[Greenpeace](/wiki/Greenpeace "Greenpeace") for using [palm
oil](/wiki/Palm_oil "Palm oil"), which the environmental organisation claimed
resulted in destruction of forest habitats for [orangutans](/wiki/Orangutan
"Orangutan") in Indonesia.[39] A YouTube video by Greenpeace went
[viral](/wiki/Viral_video "Viral video")[40] and Nestlé announced a
partnership with [The Forest
Trust](/w/index.php?title=The_Forest_Trust&action=edit&redlink=1 "The Forest
Trust \(page does not exist\)") to establish "responsible sourcing guidelines"
and ensure that its products did not have a deforestation footprint. They
aimed to achieve a fully sustainable method of palm oil harvesting by
2015.[41]

Kit Kat Milk Chocolate is made for the North American market with the
ingredient PGPR ([polyglycerol
polyricinoleate](/wiki/Polyglycerol_polyricinoleate "Polyglycerol
polyricinoleate"), E476, AKA Palsgaard PGPR 4150),[42] which is used to reduce
the amount of [cocoa butter](/wiki/Cocoa_butter "Cocoa butter") needed and as
an emulsifier.[43] The FDA has determined it to be safe for humans in amounts
up to 7.5 milligrams per kilogram of body weight. "Liver and kidney
enlargement was noticed at much higher doses."[44]

## Ingredients[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Ingredients")]

Original Kit Kat ingredients unless otherwise stated, listed by decreasing
weight: milk chocolate ([sugar](/wiki/Sugar "Sugar"), milk ingredients, [cocoa
butter](/wiki/Cocoa_butter "Cocoa butter"), [cocoa mass](/wiki/Cocoa_mass
"Cocoa mass"), [whey powder](/wiki/Whey "Whey"), [lactose](/wiki/Lactose
"Lactose"), [soya](/wiki/Soybean "Soybean") [lecithin](/wiki/Lecithin
"Lecithin"), [polyglycerol polyricinoleate](/wiki/Polyglycerol_polyricinoleate
"Polyglycerol polyricinoleate"), natural flavour), [wheat
flour](/wiki/Wheat_flour "Wheat flour"), sugar, modified [palm
oil](/wiki/Palm_oil "Palm oil"), [cocoa](/wiki/Cocoa_bean "Cocoa bean"),
[sodium bicarbonate](/wiki/Sodium_bicarbonate "Sodium bicarbonate"), soya
lecithin, [yeast](/wiki/Baker%27s_yeast "Baker's yeast"), and natural flavour.

### Europe[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Europe")]

Milk chocolate (66%) (sugar, cocoa butter, cocoa mass, dried [whole
milk](/wiki/Whole_milk "Whole milk"), cocoa mass, lactose and proteins from
whey, whey powder, [emulsifier](/wiki/Emulsion "Emulsion") (sunflower
lecithin), butterfat, flavouring), wheat flour, sugar, vegetable fat, cocoa
mass, yeast, raising agent (sodium bicarbonate), salt,
[emulsifier](/wiki/Emulsifier "Emulsifier") (soya lecithin), flavourings.

In 2006, the UK four-finger Kit Kat contained 233 dietary
[calories](/wiki/Calorie "Calorie") (kcal) (975 [kilojoules](/wiki/Kilojoule
"Kilojoule")). In 2009, the two-finger Kit Kat contained 107 calories.

In 2013, the UK Kit Kat Chunky contained 247 calories which reduced to 207
calories in 2015. This correlated to a reduction in weight by 19% from 48 g to
40 g.[45][46]

### United States[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: United States")]

**Hershey 's Kit Kat Crisp Wafers in Chocolate [1 oz]** Sugar, wheat flour,
cocoa butter, nonfat milk, chocolate, refined [palm kernel
oil](/wiki/Palm_kernel_oil "Palm kernel oil"), lactose (milk), milk fat,
contains 2% or less of: soy lecithin,
[PGPR](/wiki/Polyglycerol_polyricinoleate "Polyglycerol polyricinoleate")
(emulsifier), yeast, artificial flavor, salt, and sodium bicarbonate.

### Canada[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=16 "Edit
section: Canada")]

Milk chocolate (sugar, modified milk ingredients, cocoa butter, cocoa mass,
whey powder, lactose, soya lecithin, polyglycerol polyricinoleate, natural
flavour), wheat flour, sugar, modified palm oil, cocoa, sodium bicarbonate,
soya lecithin, yeast, Natural Flavour.

#### Dark form[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Dark form")]

Dark chocolate (sugar, unsweetened chocolate, cocoa butter, milk ingredients,
soya lecithin, salt, artificial flavour), wheat flour, sugar, modified palm
oil, unsweetened chocolate or cocoa powder, sodium bicarbonate, soya lecithin,
artificial flavour. May contain salt and/or yeast.

### Asia[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Kit_Kat&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Asia")]

Nestlé has factories in various locations in China, to supply to China and
[Hong Kong](/wiki/Hong_Kong "Hong Kong"). During the [2008 Chinese milk
scandal](/wiki/2008_Chinese_milk_scandal "2008 Chinese milk scandal"), where
[melamine](/wiki/Melamine "Melamine") was found to have tainted some milk
suppliers in China, importers in Hong Kong chose to import bars manufactured
in the United Kingdom.
